text: Family Member: And we … Doctor: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know Family Member: Okay. Doctor: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The CAT scan also looks good. Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s good. That’s pleasing isn’t it J___. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: We’re frustrated. Doctor: But he’s doing okay?

Healthcare Professional: He’s having some back pain. Doctor: Right. Family Member: We’re just kind of… Doctor: Show me where. (paper shuffling) Family Member: Yeah that’s what we wanted, that’s what we did. We just did it though. Doctor: Right here? Yeah I know that’s why it’s not. Does this hurt when I push? Patient: Not – a little bit. Doctor: A little bit. Not too bad though. Patient: No. Doctor: Is there anything that brings on the pain? Family Member: Let me tell you, I think sometimes J___ over exerts himself. Patient: I might if I have…

Family Member: but sometimes he gets snacks he shouldn’t have. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: But there’s not Metformin so we don’t have anything to combat all these sweets. So we need Doctor: Was he not taking Metformin at all? Family Member: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function, Doctor: Oh okay because of that. Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork

Family Member: He has tears in his eyes because he wants to be the man. And God is the man. He puts whoever in the position has to do whatever they have to do. Doctor: Yeah Family Member: But the fact is we’re able to do it. It doesn’t matter which pocket it comes. Patient: Well I wasn’t out there. So I’m glad I wasn’t out there. DOC Doctor: Well that was not appropriate. Family Member: And the point is in situations like that you can’t join a group, you can’t join a crowd, you have to stand out in a separate entity and say well I’m not gonna stoop to their level but I’m not gonna be stupid either. Doctor: Yeah so if are issues along the way – Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree.

Family Member: You know, I think that was the last refill. Let’s check it. Doctor: I think he needs to see us uh… Family Member: I think he’s gonna need more today. Healthcare Professional: Maybe S__ was waiting? Doctor: Yeah. Walgreens, Walmart, Healthcare Professional: Walmart pharmacy (phone dialing) Doctor: Oh you’re gonna call them and ask, perfect. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you can eat. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has? Doctor: No. Family Member: No? Doctor: No. The injection he has right now is uh, the hormone therapy, the Lupron. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: That will continue. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.

Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay? Family Member: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that. Doctor: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. The other potential side effects, there is a small chance of dropping the blood counts, which is something we will be monitoring. If you have a fever, though, temperature one oh one or higher – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - I need to know about it right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: If you have diarrhea. If you have nausea. Anything out of the ordinary. You know? Skin rash. Things like that- Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: We’re good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Any questions? Family Member: Questions? Patient: Um, do I need any medication? Family Member: No. She gave you the Promax. In a couple of weeks, you’ll need some more pain pills. Patient: Oh, okay. Family Member: Okay? Doctor: Okay. So should I give you a script today is what I’m thinking? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Because uh that way you don’t have to scramble last minute. Doctor: What is he on? The Norco, right?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thank you. Doctor: You’re welcome. Patient: Nice seeing you again. Doctor: Do you have any questions? Patient: Um no. I’m I’m good.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like-

Family Member 1: See my daughter thought it was a placebo. I hope she doesn't Doctor: No and you know that at this stage of your cancer, you should never be on a placebo only trial that's actually unethical. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: So it should always be like, whatever is the standard, maybe it's a chemo, maybe it's a pill, but we do a lot of combo therapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: So one might be like, “Well, okay, you get chemo, you get chemo, but you'll get the extra pill and you'll get the placebo extra pill.” We don't know who's who but everyone gets chemo. So at the root of it, if everybody gets chemo, you're getting treatment and you're just trying to see if the extra thing does anything. Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill?

Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping.

Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them. Patient: Yeah. That does help. Family Member 1: So, okay. Family Member 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take? Family Member 1: Like 10? Doctor: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter. Family Member 2: Mhmm.

Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different. Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard.

Family Member 1: Well I’m on blood thinners every day. Patient: So M___ is the next person to come in? Doctor: M____'s coming right in. Family Member 2: Can I ask you a question? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: So he has taken some Ambien once in a while to sleep, is that okay or no? Doctor: We'll we'll check the protocol to make sure there's no future drug interaction, but I think it's fine Family Member 2: Okay, do you want a prescription referral? Do you need a prescription? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Is that okay? I don't have any left. Doctor: We always prefer Restiril, have you ever been? So that's actually probably a better sleeper. Family Member 2: Restiril.

Family Member 1: Write that down. Doctor: It's more like she’s going to be tough for you. And the mask can only do so much. Family Member 1: In case she picks up a virus from her. Family Member 2: She goes to classes around other kids. Doctor: Absolutely. Family Member 2: Can the mask cover it? Doctor: It's just not ideal. You know, if I if you know, she's already got the snotty nose and all that. Family Member 1: Fam1 hold back. Doctor: You know kind of maybe just don't want to hang there. You know, they're not sick all the time. But sometimes you don't know like a fever comes after they’ve been crabby for the day, and you've been exposed. So just trying to minimize- Family Member 1: So let me repeat this. On the chemo- it’s safe for him to be around her. Doctor: Yeah, she’s not getting cancer. Family Member 2: He can kiss her.

Patient: Uh I try not to do that. Family Member 1: Yeah. What about using their toilet? See what I’m saying, while he’s there. Doctor: So same thing, I would just bring a pair of gloves, your own towels and then you wipe and just get a bag that you throw off the stuff. You know what's hard is toddlers get into everything. And you just can't help it. They're curious. Family Member 1: Well, it wouldn't be just for the toddler. Like we all use the main bathroom. There's the upstairs. She's still in diapers, so she has where she not trained yet. Okay, but myself the one that you come in the door, I can't keep climbing the stairs and using the bathroom. Right? And that he has to discipline he still has to disinfect, right? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. So you you get one of those Clorox thingy that you pull out. Patient: Yeah. I know. Family Member 1: At the hospital. Doctor: You can get food gloves if you want, you know? Family Member 1: Yeah we have hospital gloves. Family Member 2: And then put them in a bag. Doctor: That's it. Patient: Yeah nothing complicated.

Patient: Yeah nothing complicated. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 1: Flush twice. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 2: He’s wiping the toilet, but he’s also wiping the sink with a separate wipe. Doctor: He’s wiping the toilet. So kind of like where you're at, just swipe around it and then when everything blows up, boom in here. Good. Good. Family Member 1: And so when he washes his hands? Doctor: Doc Same thing. Patient: Pat Yeah. Family Member 2: What about her mom? A____’s two. Her mom. She's pregnant. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 2: Can he be around her? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, as long as she’s not sick. Come on M___. Come in here smells so good.

Family Member 1: Let's go to the kitchen, not the bathroom. Patient: Yeah, I won't be doing that. Doctor: Yeah, I think it you know, it's always hard. Patient: I don’t want to get too much involved. Doctor: I mean, the easiest way to get Patient: I just won’t go there. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, good idea. Doctor: I just wont go there. Healthcare Professional: How old is she? Family Member 1: Yeah but the Mother is. Doctor: Yeah, but they’re always into things and we talked about this. Family Member 1: She’s not out of her first trimester. Yeah.

Family Member 3: So um, we are worried about him being around the mother that is newly pregnant, she gets her first ultrasound right now. So what do you think? Doctor: Well, they're, you know- Family Member 1: If they ask us for dinner. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, it's sort of you know, you're you're just having social contact is okay. Family Member 1: It’s okay. So he could be around them. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Family Member 2: Okay, so you're going to look into the Restiril possibly. Doctor: He's got sleep issues, so we'll have to see the Restiril and drug interactions, Healthcare Professional: yeah, there's a lot of drug interactions. Doctor: Yeah I remember. Healthcare Professional: There’s a full list.

Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to – Doctor: Okay. Patient: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me. Doctor: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day. Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay.

Doctor: you know it’s not in his head, it’s here and that’s the only part that could go wrong. Family Member: So doctor he hears that it’s okay for him to be on that motorcycle? Doctor: What I’m saying is, for me, I don’t advise it. But if you say medically if there is some reason you can’t be on it, no. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he asks me is there a medical reason why I can’t be on it? No. Do I think it’s a good idea? Not really.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I’m not, I’m not the one that can tell you. You have to use common sense. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s not like you’re going up north, you’re going to F__. Patient: Yeah, well Doc I went to C__. Doctor: I got ya, but that was way before you got sick. Patient: Well not really. Doctor: Okay, I’m just saying. Patient: You know I’m just saying doc, I doc, you know. Doctor: Yeah. That’s gonna be your decision. Okay. Family Member: Excuse me. Doctor: Yep, Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But when you’re on pills like that, experimental ones – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You don’t want to have some big surgery, be scheduled in the middle of it. Doesn’t make sense. Because you have to do one at a time. Patient: I got you. Doctor: Because it’s a big sur – I mean it’s a big one. (Cell phone rings) Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this –

Patient: Why? Doctor: Why? You’re straining – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Everything is loose. Patient: Yeah. I want it – I want it to be loose. Doctor: No. No. No. You’ll, you’ll bleed easy, you strain just a little bit – you’re gonna bleed. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you have to have loose bowels. That means – Patient: That’s what I’m talkin’ about. Doctor: Soft. Stool softeners. Patient: Stool softeners. Doctor: Absolutely. Patient: They ain’t workin’ like they’re supposed to, doc!

Patient: I -- I’m preparing for that. Doctor: He’s prepared. It’s what he loves to do. Patient: Yeah. I’m – Doctor: But I think her point is you just do it within reason. If you ride twelve hours a day, you’re not drinkin’ fluids, you’re not takin’ your stool softeners, you don’t want to mess yourself up – Patient: I’m --- just listen. Listen to this, doc. Doctor: That’s hard. That’s all. Patient: Listen to this. Listen to this. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m gonna do all that. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay? Because I’m wearin’ the, the pad now anyway. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Let me, let me ask this here, doc. Doctor: Yes? Patient: So, what is this trial that you’re talkin’ about? Doctor: Okay. Patient: Tell me more. Doctor: Doc This is – you’ve had the XTANDI. Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s sorta breaking through, right? You’re cancer’s already sort of figured out how it works. Patient: Right. Doctor: You’re options are A different standard of care pill, but we worry that if you go from that pill to the other pill, we don’t get a lot of mileage out of that because it’s too similar. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So then we could talk about chemo. (Pause)

Family Member: But what she’s talkin’ about – Doctor: Is a treatment. Family Member: Exactly. As long as you – ‘cuz my sister’s father deals with the prostate. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Family Member: He gets chemotherapy. Okay? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And there’s no other – nothin’ for him. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Besides that. You have something else besides that! You, you have another choice. So, either you try (Pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Well, it’s a change, you know. It’s just this, this cancer’s just letting you know that it’s doin’ it’s thing every step of the way. You haven’t had two seconds of a break, and it’s hard. And I know one thing you love to do is ride your bike, and it’s hard to do when things aren’t right down there. Whether it’s pain or – Patient: Well, doc, you know --

Patient: You gonna put me to sleep or what? Doctor: Oh, yeah. Yeah. You’ll be fine. Patient: Oh, man! No!!! Doc! C’mon! Doctor: You’ll be fine! Family Member: Seriously? Patient: How you goin’, do whatcha, you goin’ up my ass? What are you doin’? Doctor: No!!!! What is your fixation about the lower body parts? (Laughs) Patient: Well then – when you go -- how you gonna get to – how you gonna do the biopsy? You gonna cut me open? Doctor: No! You lay down on the CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They numb up an area right around here or here – Patient: Right.

Patient: We’ll reevaluate. We’ll take a look at it, you understand? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Maybe in October or December – Doctor: Okay. Patient: Of next year. Doctor: Mr. L_, I know from talking with you the last time. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’. Patient: But will I – wait a minute, wait a minute, wait a minute, but Dr. P_ just talked about one bag! And you come out with two bags, man! Doctor: Well, you might need two bags. Patient: Woooooooo. Doctor: Where’s the bowel gonna get re-routed? It’s gotta poop somewhere, and you’re got a connection. Patient: Wooooooo. Doctor: It’s two bad organs.

Patient: Because it’s – Doctor: It’s connected! Patient: Connected, and then it’ll still be goin’ in the pad, and if it go – Doctor: So, I’m sayin’ – Patient: In that pad in that area. Doctor: I know you. I would rather that you know there’s a potential of two bags. Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember?

Patient: I need a, either a stronger stool softener – Doctor: Or more. Patient: Or more. Doctor: So that. You’re takin’ Senokot. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Those two red pills? Patient: Right. Doctor: You take it twice a day. That doesn’t do the job? You take it three times a day. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: Okay? Morning, noon, and night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: So that, so that’ll cover that. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Do I still get the prune juice and all that shit or not? Doctor: If you – well, you may not need it. Patient: I may not need it. Okay. Okay. So, we’ll just try the pills first. Doctor: Yes. And then you keep goin’ with your pain medicine – Patient: Keep goin’ with my pain medicine – Doctor: Take that as you need it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: And then – so we got that out of the way. Doctor: Got that out of the way.

Patient: Then you’re gonna schedule me up to get the yoo-yoo. Doctor: The yoo-yoo’s the biopsy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: He knows he has to have it. He knows he just had a scan. M_’s gonna go as quick as she can to get things rollin’. So. Healthcare Professional 2: Well, can you come Tuesday? (Laughs) Patient: Next Tuesday? Healthcare Professional 2: ‘Cuz we had a cancellation. Doctor: Okay! If it’s for Mr. L_, it’s fine. Patient: Next, next Tuesday? What day is, what day, what date is that? Healthcare Professional 2: What date? Doctor: Ummmm. Healthcare Professional 2: Ummmmm.

Patient: Could I give away all my ladders? Doctor: Did you put it in the garage sale? I was going to do a drive-by and take your ladder. Patient: So what makes you think I may have fallen again? Doctor: Because I can’t, K just mentioned that she thought you did. Patient: Oh. Doctor: But it might have been last time. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right?

Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Where the pain, where the pain was? Doctor: Uh hum, well there, they radiated you from the outside. You laid down and they beamed it to you, right. This is internal. So when they push it in your bloodstream it goes all around and it lands in the area of the bone that has the cancer. Family Member: Is there side effects? Doctor: Oh yeah, there’s always side effects. Because it’s radiation, some of the side effects could be you know reduced or lower amounts of blood cells in your system, so people could get low white cells, red cells, platelets. Those are your three guys that I always watch out for and in some people, it’s a pretty big dip and you don’t come back. Very rare, but it’s a possibility. Family Member: What do you mean a dip?

Family Member: What do you mean a dip? Doctor: Meaning it destroys too much. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And there’s no coming back. But you know in terms of how much does that occur, it’s very rare. Could it occur—sure, and I tend to see it in folks who have had a lot of therapy, especially chemo. You’ve had pills and more pills, a little smattering of radiation and a Provenge, and a partridge in a pear tree. So where you are coming in is your bone marrow is not as compromised as a person who had chemo. I’m not saying that you couldn’t get it after chemo, but the perfect person to give it in is a person who is actually having some pain, which you are, a person that otherwise is in good shape, and has a good enough bone marrow reserve, which you do, and it’s not related to any other treatment like steroids and things like that, where if I were to offer chemo, that would be part of the package. Again, not impossible for us to go down the chemo route, but that’s also the next discussion. But for this, I think it’s reasonable to talk to the radiation doctor about it because you’ll want to know pros and cons. So the bone marrow is the thing I always worry about, but for my other patients, and I’ve had many go through it, the other part that it could affect would be your gut. So diarrhea, stomach upset, not so much nausea and vomiting but just more like you know you’ve got the poops kind of thing. But for you it’s obviously something we could regulate because you could get Imodium, you know. You could get treatment. A lot of my patients have it during the time around you know the week that you get injected and then nothing else. So that’s kind of where it is. Oh, and if you have cancer that’s not in the bone, like liver or lungs, which you don’t have, but those patients, they don’t; you know they shouldn’t be treated with this medicine because that medicine that I’m thinking about for you is only for bone. So it will not go to liver or anywhere else. Family Member: So the pain that he’s having - Doctor: Is in bone. Family Member: And how big of a spot does he have there – on his hip and lower leg, upper leg. Doctor: Yeah, I mean it’s not a humongous spot. But it still is enough for it’s - Family Member: Causing pain. Doctor: Uh hum. Family Member: I thought maybe he might have hurt his self when he was carrying boxes up and down stairs Doctor: No, now we’re down now, though, right? No more. Patient: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight.

Patient: Well, I don’t think it was so much carrying boxes because my kids and my wife wouldn’t let me carry weight. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But you did. Patient: But it was, no but it was never a heavy weight. It was just, yeah, I did do a lot of up and down the stairs. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Steps. Patient: And I noticed you know like the first day that Doctor: Right. Family Member: Could that trigger? Doctor: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think – Patient: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for - Doctor: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. But it could be worsened because you were just moving. Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate?

Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate? Doctor: Uhn-uhn. This stuff that’s liquid goes everywhere in the bone. Family Member: Ohh! Doctor: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter. Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months. Doctor: Yeah, like they give it to you - it’s like one minute, and you’re done for the month. Family Member: Does he have to keep that catheter in there for the whole month? Doctor: No. Family Member: Oh good. Doctor: Like you put it in (makes mimicking sound) Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking.

Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel –

Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it. Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t.

Patient: I wasn’t on a ladder. Doctor: Uh huh. And I think you know; I mean your body will tell you. If he really poops out, no matter what he really wants to do, it’s not gonna happen. But I think you got to get off the Xtandi, which will help you with your energy. I’ll start the process for the Xofigo, and I’m gonna give you the side-effects sheet to start when Dr. ____ reviews the whole thing with you. Family Member: How long will this take? Doctor: It’s once a month. Oh you mean the – oh it’s like a few weeks. Family Member: So. Doctor: Yeah, the Xofigo. Family Member: Xofigo. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Do you think he’s qualified to go away on a vacation for a couple of weeks? Doctor: Uh hum, yeah – when are you going? Healthcare Professional: When are you going on vacation? Doctor: Yeah, I get to go.

Family Member: Well he’s been pretty active. Patient: No, I’ve been pretty active. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He’ll fall asleep on a dime, but so do I. Doctor: Me, too. Now I wish I had a clinical study to offer you at this point, but our Xofigo plus something requires your disease to actually be worse than it is (not that I’m wishing you were on that) Patient: Right. Doctor: so at this moment. One, stop Xtandi; two, we’re going to give you some Xofigo paperwork and you’re going to do some of the – just give him some of the - Healthcare Professional: Lupron. Doctor: Lupron. And then we’ll send you on to see Dr. ___ for a consult. All of that is not a huge rush, but we’re just gonna move it along. Family Member: Yeah, because we’re leaving February fifth, so. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So.

Patient: So you don’t want me to take Xtandi at all anymore? Healthcare Professional: No, stop it. Family Member: Can we donate it to somebody that needs it? Healthcare Professional: Yeah, bring it back in. Doctor: Bring it back to us and we’ll make sure it gets recycled to the next person, absolutely. Family Member: To the next person who needs it. Doctor: And we have a process to do that. Family Member: Somebody that needs it because I know how expensive it is. Doctor: Yes, and we appreciate that. Family Member: Yeah, we’ll bring it back. Doctor: Okay, sounds like a plan. Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything?

Family Member: So he won’t get; will he – does he need nausea medication for this drug or anything? Doctor: Typically not; obviously we can, oh you know, he’s such a typical guy. But yes, Dr. ___ can prescribe that because he has a set thing because this is his program to run. So I’m just hovering nearby. Family Member: I think he was the one that actually diagnosed you with cancer when I told him to do the bone scan. Doctor: Oh my gosh! That’s been a long time then. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Yeah, because he was just going to start him on radiation and I go well - Doctor: No, he saw Dr. ___ in O____ when I was there many moons ago. Family Member: Because I told him, “His dad suffered, died from prostate cancer, could you at least do a scan on him and make sure he doesn’t have bone cancer?” And they did. Doctor: Yeah. And poof! Family Member: And bam, it showed up! Doctor: Told you you were weird. Patient: So then, yes, so then it was at that point that I went to ___ for a consult. Family Member: Uh hum, yeah.

Healthcare Professional: So quit climbing ladders and falling. Doctor: That’s – I was going to do a drive-by and get his stinking ladder. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Let her shoot you up, my friend. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, I’m going to get this rolling with Dr. ___. Patient: So it seems to me though that - Doctor: Yeah? Patient: I come off the Xtandi now; I’m not having, I’m not taking anything to treat the cancer. Doctor: Yeah, right, until you get to the next one, which is this radium or Xofigo. It starts with another “X” name. So don’t get confused. So it’s not Xtandi; it’s Xofigo. Patient: But it would seem to me it makes more sense to keep taking Xtandi till I’m on that treatment. Doctor: You would think so but your cancer has figured it out. (pause) Family Member: So could it start like the first of January and then -

Family Member: Yeah. I saw that this morning. Doctor: Oh, my. Family Member: North and south was shut down. Doctor: Oh, boy. Patient: No south of us Doctor: Yeah. It was police incident. I’m not sure exactly what they say it was but- Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing.

Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time- Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: I thought that was concentrating on that bundle that was in the lumbar region. Doctor: Yep. It was. Patient: It wasn’t, it wasn’t throughout where I have cancer throughout the spine. Doctor: Well, it’s, it’s, kind of altogether. You know? So it’s the lumbar, it’s the lower lumbar is where your- Patient: Radiation treatment was. Doctor: Yeah. Exactly. Patient: So it wasn’t doing anything up here or the middle of the spine. Doctor: No. No. Right. And that would be true for proton. Protons are you know there’s a spot I want and- Patient: Site specific. Doctor: Very. So the question is do you color right up to the line you know with a two millimeter ballpoint pen or do you have a five millimeter ballpoint pen. So you’re trying to cut it out and draw an outline. You know? Will you get more precise? Yeah you might get more precise but is there any meaning to that for the patient. And that’s what we don’t know. So new stuff. I think we have to keep an eye on that technology to see what they think. Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: There’s probably, I think there’s only like seven or eight of these proton sites around the country. So ah Family Member: I think B___ is one of them. Doctor: Oh, yeah, B___’s up. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean we were, you know, supposed to get one up in F___. I don’t know what’s going to happen with that but nonetheless B___ is right here. Family Member: But say if his rib spots start- causing him pain - Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Can they go in specifically with a proton or? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Would it be needed, a proton be needed, or can regular radiation take care of it? Doctor: So typically it’s just regular radiation. So right now as far as I’m aware it’s sort of like isolated rib treatment for proton is not commonplace. Family Member: Mm Hmm.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. Um, but, you know, we’d have to ask the proton guys for that. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well then being that the radiation is site specific Doctor: Mm Mmm. Patient: and you’ve created this area- Doctor: Yep. Patient: Why wouldn’t we go site specific in all the other areas that I have- Family Member: You don’t want too much. Too much will kill ya’. Patient: -that you have imaging to know where it is? Doctor: Well, because it doesn’t change the outcome. So your treatment is so that the pain gets better as in kill the cells, no pain. If you have pain elsewhere, you could consider that. But if it’s just a pluck off the areas that you think has cancer, it doesn’t change the overall status of your disease. You know? You don’t live longer with it but you might get some down sides. You know? Like she said the more you radiate the more your bone marrow is hit. So you’ll get a consequence off of that where you might lose some cells. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So you don’t want to treat them unless you know what you’re going to get a result of. So with radiation right now the result is gee I hope my pain is controlled. That’s what I wanted for you. The second one would be gee I hope my pain is controlled and my spine gets stabilized. Whew. And then number three would be I hope the cancer doesn’t come back there. You know? Now it’s been burned out.

Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And things like that where it looks good in the bottle but there’s no regulation on what’s inside. Remember we talked about how difficult that can be sometimes? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And then I don’t know what’s going to happen if your liver poops out on me then we’re in trouble. Family Member: Right. Because it can affect his liver. Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right?

Patient: No. It seems to mirror what I was experiencing before. Doctor: Because I think between now and the six weeks that stuffs coming out of you, you decide whether, you know, if it’s looking like even week three of our six-week little holiday here, you go, yeah, you know what, this stuff’s really not getting any better. You call us. We’ll just order the MRI. Poof. Done. Family Member: He’s supposed to see Dr. V___ in a couple of weeks. Doctor: Good. Good. Patient: I think it’s July second - Doctor: Okay. Patient: - I see him. Doctor: I’m sure he’s going to be happy with your progress, but we’ll see. Again, if you see him then, and you’re like, ah, not better, hello, he can order the MRI. Family Member: Yeah. He’s been taking the Norco and stuff where before he wasn’t taking that. Doctor: How’s the rest of you? Family Member: Tired. Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a-

Patient: Yeah. Sleep, sleep is a- Doctor: Listen. Your blood sugar is dismal. Let’s just talk about tired and a blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: Will make you tired. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Family Member: Well, you’ve got one there. Doctor: Huh? Oh, yeah. Family Member: I know I get, I know I get, I’m tired when mine’s high. Sometimes I had a two, and I cut out all sorts of carbs, all carbs basically. Doctor: Three eighty five. People don’t walk around with blood sugar of three eighty five. Family Member: I told him do the diet I’m doing. Patient: Now when I put it all together I’ve got some of my stuff in there. Family Member: Quit eating all that bread and cereal and stuff. Doctor: Yes. What are you doing? Family Member: Do my diet, honey.

Family Member: Right. Just quit getting – we can’t have spaghetti for Father’s Day. Doctor: No. You can have squash spaghetti. Family Member: Yeah. I could see my daughter-in-law making that. (Laughter) Doctor: I’m just saying, you can have spaghetti, just not pasta. Family Member: Pasta. Right. Not cereal. We need to get rid of the Special K. Doctor: No cereal. No bread. No pasta. Patient: So then I’m eating, uh- Family Member: My diet. Doctor: You’re just eating protein. Patient: Seven days a week eating eggs. Doctor: Well, there’s other foods other than eggs. But carbs for you are like, forget it. Forget it. They’re disastrous. Family Member: Cancer feeds on it.

Family Member: Right? Am I wrong there? Doctor: Well, it isn’t. You know what it is? It creates an unhealthy environment for you. And for all the other stuff I may potentially have to do for you, to you, however we want to say that, I need you functioning and that diabetes can’t be in my way. Gosh darn it. Doctor: Yeah. Plus unregulated, and I mean this up and down, your body just doesn’t like it. So the steady state might be alright at a hemoglobin A one C of seven two but your every day, what you get is tired. You crash. You go back up. You’re good. You crash. You’re tired. You come back up. That’s not, boom, okay. Patient: So then like I again explained to Dr. W___ about my, about my fatigue. Doctor: Um hum. Yes. Patient: Is my lack of uninterrupted sleep. I just don’t get it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I don’t get – there’s never a night that I get three or four hours uninterrupted sleep. Doctor: Cause you’re peeing? Patient: Um, yes. Doctor: Yeah. So what time do you stop drinking? Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter)

Patient: Every time I get up, I drink some more water. (Laughter) Doctor: That’s why you keep peeing. Patient: But everybody told me to drink more water. Family Member: No. During the day. Doctor: During the day. You should shut your water drinking at seven o’clock. Doctor: Yes. And then you’ll stop peeing at night. And then you’ll wake up and drink all day until you stop at seven o’clock. Family Member: When they were doing the (Xofigo) Patient: No. Well, they were having a problem getting my- Doctor: Yes. Exactly. Well, the problem is, it’s just this bad cycle you’re in. You know? Then you’re tired. It comes around and around. Family Member: Yeah just make better choices. Doctor: Okay. Glad we had this conversation about your diabetes in a prostate cancer clinic, but that’s actually number one. Doctor: Plus, you know, you’re getting that stupid, you know, Lupron shot from us, or, all the time. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Are we the ones that give it to you? Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Yeah. K___ gives it. Doctor: Yeah. From us. I’m like why did I think it wasn’t us? Oh, it’s us. And you know we make your diabetes like even worse. So I feel partly responsible. I’m just trying to make sure you stay healthy. No carbs. Patient: Okay. Then, we’re going to see you, see you in six weeks? Doctor: That’s it. Enjoy yourself. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Have fun. Enjoy the weather. Patient: Let’s see. Six weeks is going to put us in middle of July? Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: End of July.

Family Member: So what is – can he take anything to help him sleep? Like natural? Doctor: You can try melatonin. Family Member: Melatonin. That’s right. Doctor: I suggest stop drinking at seven p.m. and you’ll be a miracle. You won’t even get up that much. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then you’ll say, oh, my, gosh, I’m awake and I didn’t get up. Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go.

Patient: Well, I feel good. Doctor: Okay. We’ll have to see what your PSA is but obviously last time it’s gone down, and I’m thrilled. Patient: Well, let’s hope it’s gone down. So we haven’t gotten it back? Doctor: Um hum. Not from today but we’ll call ya’. Family Member: Oh yeah. I need to give the nurse the new phone number. Doctor: Oh. Well holler to him. He’ll write it and pass it on to K___ too just in case. Patient: What’s the number? Doctor: Excellent. Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that again? I’m sorry. Family Member: Hum? Healthcare Professional: Can you repeat that? Family Member: Yes. (Patient gives phone number.)

Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of- Doctor: Like. No. I think it’s okay. I think K___ has everything. So we’re good. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. I just want to double check. You scared the heck out of me last time. So I’m just gonna I don’t know keep an eye on you just a little bit closer - Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: -until I’m confident that I can let you go for three months. Family Member: Right. (Laughter)

Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Questions. Patient: Well, the first question is of course- Doctor: Yep. Patient: -is side effects. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah.

Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay. Doctor: When it comes to trials, if it's something like, oh, give this new pill to get we give that to you. We don't bill the insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But that Xtandi, we still have to do what we got to do. Obviously, we're gonna support you in any which way we can. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But yeah, before anything drastic happens, and if you sometimes want to just talk to social work about what is the next step, they can guide you there too. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so.

Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I know I have an imaging scheduled for, what was it S____, the--? Healthcare Professional: Uh, we're going to do it the fourteeth. Patient: Fourteenth? Healthcare Professional: So it's two weeks from today. Doctor: So two weeks from now. Healthcare Professional: And then treatment on the twenty first.

Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean, I was surviving--I was able to get by with work and stuff, it was-- Family Member: You got really--you were really, really tired. Doctor: I may just adjust you today because if we can keep that eye and, you know, everything else from getting worse-- Patient: Yeah, the drops have been wonderful. Doctor: --because the nerves affecting things is a big problem. If that happens, then that's tougher to reverse. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So let's go one notch slightly lower in terms of your dose. Patient: Okay. Yeah, I missed it yesterday, I was going to come in all dressed up as a doctor, and-- Doctor: Yep. Healthcare Professional: So we just need to do a date clarification 'cause- so the pharmacy can use the last order the last time. Just have to change today’s date, so.

Patient: Now I get the impression he might do more than just the two that were were pressing right now. Doctor: I think that would be important for us because Patient: Yeah. Doctor: we may need to you know not treat them all and leave one so that you’re actually eligible- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -for the trial, which is a terrible thing to say. Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the

Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name) Patient: S__ (spells name) Doctor: K__ (spells name) Patient: Let me just see what I have here for his. Doctor: Uh, and that’s what – February twelfth? Patient: That’s the first date of radiation. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: and you think what is he doing. And he’s visualizing what he’s going to do. And he said it’s important to visualize that you succeed Doctor: Correct. Patient: because he said if you visualize you’re going to go off the ramp; he said you’re going to go off the ramp. Patient: That was a while ago. Doctor: That was a long time ago, like ABC or something, “Wide World of Sports.” Patient: Yeah, it was ABC, yeah. Doctor: Yeah, GOSH, thanks for the flash back. Patient: Oh yeah. Doctor: I like stay positive. But you know me to be positive anyway. Patient: So we might want to do a blood test today? Doctor: Yeah, just to get everything on the record here because the last one was obviously August. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Seventeen.

Patient: All right, right. Doctor: We have a creatinine from when you did a quick you know CAT scan. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But we’ll need; I’m sure we’ll need the full megillah. Patient: So what I need to just walk down there? Doctor: We may end up drawing it here. OH, OH, somebody’s eavesdropping. Come on in now. Healthcare Professional 1: Hi there. Hi, Mr. L___. Good to see you. How are you doing? Patient: Great, how are you? Doctor: Ah, I said, “You might need some blood work today.” Oh okay, that’s my ticket out; good-bye.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ours isn’t back yet, but his is going up. Patient: Yeah I mean I… Doctor: Mhmm Patient: I think I started chemo and I was in the low thirties. I went down in to twenties and I’m back up to thirty I think the last one from B______. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. You know the lymph nodes are starting to grow again. Just plumpier um Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah.

Patient: I feel pretty good. Doctor: …you know whatever that end date is and it probably should have been your last infusion if we’re gonna.. Patient: It probably will be and I mean I Doctor: Yeah. Patient: think that the decision point, I see him a week from today. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay . Patient: And then he’ll have the um PSA number at that point in time. Doctor: Yeah and by then we’ll know what trial makes sense um to offer… Patient: You know I do see on the internet, I think it was a… Doctor: Yeah Patient: British article about immunotherapy with prostate cancer… Doctor: Mhmm, Yes. Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success.

Patient: …and they said they’re starting to see some success. Doctor: Yes. It’s um you know the ones that we have just for prostate doesn’t allow people who’ve had chemo, but we have a couple more in the phase one group that potentially will. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’re gonna tap into those. There’s also um this new trial that’s looking at PSMA that I’m quite interested in. Just a matter of if we have a slot or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It just opened, it just opened. Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow.

Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now. Doctor: Yeah Patient: But the quality of life has been reasonably good. Doctor: That’s- Yeah. That’s that’s the best part to hear. Absolutely. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Good. Patient: So I mean it’s just um and then I had um breakfast with this guy who is a couple years ahead of me in high school and he…

Patient: Right, exactly right. Doctor: Awesome. Sounds like a plan. Uh as soon as we locate the right one you’ll be the first to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um I think M______ wanted to just say hi. Stick her head in here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we all eyeball you and then (sound MD makes noise for effect) Patient: Yeah so she can see my hair style. Patient: I- You know I was getting so little in the back I just decided… Doctor: Aww. Patient: I’m just gonna shave it all off. Doctor: Did you do that? Really? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me see. Yeah Patient: Yeah… Doctor: it looks pretty good. Pretty smooth. Patient: Yeah and it – this is not from my shaving. I ran into the garage door because I I Doctor: Ohh. Patient: didn’t allow it to get high enough. I bent my head - Doctor: Because you were in a rush. Patient: I was in a rush to get out. (Laughs) Doctor: Stop that! Alright sit tight here. Let me go get her. Patient: Okay. Doctor: She just wants to wave and kick you out. Patient: Okay. Thank you very much.

Patient: There’s the first one is – is whoops, one of them is from um March of fifteen to um November of fifteen and then the second one is January of sixteen to March of seventeen. Doctor: Okay. And I forgot, I think I asked you this before, do you have a nephrologist? Patient: No. I do not. Doctor: This is your primary care person checking it right? Patient: Yeah. But whoever was doing – ordering the vitals. Doctor: Yeah, gotcha. Patient: The vitals, the vitals, the uh what do they call it, comes in a comprehensive uh metabolic, metabolic panel. Doctor: Yeah, you were as high as one point seven five, May twenty-sixteen? Patient: No I think in fifteen I was even higher than that. Doctor: And then um (papers shuffling) Patient: I don’t know that your medication is the one that’s the problem. Doctor: It’s probably not.

Patient: And it’s basically a high protein low carb uh kind of a program. Doctor: Ah. Patient: And so I am processing more protein. Doctor: Yep. Patient: And I believe, I believe that protein is one of the things that can drive the creatinine up. Doctor: That is true. Patient: Okay. So how do I… Family Member: It’s being done for die- his diabetic condition. Doctor: Right. Patient: Yeah. So how do I counter that? Doctor: That’s where you have to go to a nephrologist ‘cause they’re smarter than me. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: They gotta work with the kidney and in your case it really is the kidney.

Patient: And my hydration has always been plus a little bit in there. So I think that that might be a temporary ah thing like for the last two days. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay. Patient: It could have been – and my schedule is pretty weird. Family Member: Oh yes. Doctor: Is it easing up so you can take some fluids or am I giving you fluids today? (pause) Family Member: Oh boy. Patient: No it’s – no… …it’s easy, it’s easy enough yeah… Family Member: If he thinks of it he can get it anywhere he is. Patient: Because I drink water. I like water.
