Family Member: Yes. Doctor: You’re gonna have to make it an effort then get in to see the nephrology folks… Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: …I had called M___ but I haven’t had a call back. Doctor: I’m not - I think we need you to sign something. But I’ll go step out and see what K____ wants to do. Family Member: We will do that. Yes. Patient: Okay, good. Family Member: That would be helpful. Doctor: Um what was the other thing? Patient: Well you took me off of this thing… Doctor: Yes, yes. Family Member: Yes. That’s the other question. Patient: So… Doctor: So we’re gonna try to put you back on. Patient: Okay, that’s fine…

Patient: Uh (relation) Doctor: So it’s not direct. It would be well I’m super tired or my stomach doesn’t feel good then I eat and drink less. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then you’re dehydrated and your - and organ like kidney or liver takes a hit. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Gotcha. Doctor: That’s the problem. Patient: I’m not eating less. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I do feel that I’m eating better… Um… Family Member: Mhmm. Doctor: Yeah because you got a week off.

Family Member: Yeah, that’s what it is Healthcare Professional: Breaking bad news Doctor: Yes, yes, I thought he meant Breaking Bad like the TV Family Member: Yeah, that's what I’m thinking Healthcare Professional: No, No Doctor: I’m, like, did J___ do something I’m not aware of? (laughter) Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that.

Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good.

Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: I mean, I think the rise is so small. We know it is just starting to breakthrough. Family Member: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: But, probably can’t definitively prove it right now on scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the scans are so nonsensitive. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. If you’re taking a medicine, it is supposed to make your PSA go down, and it starts rising up. That’s probably breaking through. So, we need to pile one more drug on there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s all of the trials out in the U.S. are now like that. You’re trucking along with Enza, and uh-oh, it’s not working. We slap another medicine on there to see if we can help it. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: So, the two medicines that you’ve got potential… Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Patient: What are the side effects? Doctor: Well, tiredness. Hi? Patient: Well, that was what? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Doctor: That was Xtandi. So, tiredness. One of them has a low platelet issue. Like, you take it, and your platelets are gone. You stop it; the platelets come back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t feel bad from that, Patient: No.

Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh. Doctor: But, it’s usually letters and numbers. Ummm. But, they work in a class of drugs that we think are highly active in prostate cancer, so it’s about five different drugs that are in this space, targeting the same pathway. So, we just don’t know which one has an opening. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: And, when would that start? Doctor: M___ will tell us, but probably, you know, obviously in the new year, and it maybe second or third week… Patient: Well, they took seven vials of blood…

Patient: The twelfth, and we’ll be gone for the twentieth. We’re going to Phoenix then. Doctor: Okay. Let’s, we’ll incorporate that all in. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s all. Or, if we have to, then we will start the twenty-first when you come back or the twenty-second. Patient: Gotcha. Okay. Family Member: Mm-hmm. Doctor: Plenty of time! Plenty of time. Patient: So, so, so it’s not bad news that …. Doctor: No, I don’t think it’s bad news at all. We were all kinda, “Ohhhhhh. Maybe there’s a thing in the liver or whatever.” You’re good. Patient: Good. Family Member: Oh, good. Patient: Okay.

Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Well it is doing everything it’s supposed to do because if you look at your lymph node, remember the bones hardly ever change. Patient: Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new. Patient: Right. Doctor: And it hardly ever goes to you know oh look it’s all gone. Maybe you get one or two things Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and you just don’t see it, but your lymph nodes are substantially smaller. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Substantially, so this sucker’s totally working because you know the drop of your PSA not including today, but in the past have all been down.

Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So I’m fine with it. We fuss over big joints, hips, legs… Patient: Okay. Doctor: Shoulders because they can crack. Family Member: We were thinking it was right and not left. Patient: Yeah something to do with the hip replacement thought too. Doctor: Well the hip replacement always glows so then we always look for the other side to make sure that you don’t have a matching set. Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So the issue is if you start to feel it because you’re working more, or you’re lounging more, or doing whatever more up north and you’re aware, but it’s more of an awareness thing not we’re about to do this. Patient: Um hum, um hum. Doctor: People know and this is kind of like you know your right hip wasn’t functioning well before.

Patient: Was that Dr. Y or W? Family Member: I don’t know. Wayne maybe. I don’t know. Patient: Somebody made a comment that… Doctor: I think you know so all the studies, they try to go up to ten. They try to go up to ten. So we just try to chunk – you’re a little off cycle because you know we started off with the vitamin C thing so three more and then… Family Member: Seriously, we need three more? Doctor: Yeah. We want ten total. Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Oh. Doctor: The key is you’re still – you know it’s still shrinking. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Until I get you – you could get five more, but if you beat me by getting your PSA to zero, then I’ll stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: How’s that for a challenge? Family Member: So if it comes back today and it’s zero? Doctor: Fine. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s up to you so don’t screw up it’s not me. Patient: No she’s got it wrong, but thank you. Doctor: But if you guys don’t go over, honestly they’re gonna scream at me. Patient: Okay. Okay. Okay..

Patient: That gives me goose bumps. They never show up because my skin’s changed. Doctor: Yeah so here you go. (Laughs) Patient: Alright I’m gonna shut up and just let you keep talking. Doctor: Yeah well you know you need more chemo. That’s really what you need (laughs) Patient: I do? Doctor: You do. How ‘bout that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But your insurance today is not playing nice and it’s not letting us treat you today. Family Member: What? Doctor: Uh huh. Yes. K__’s yelling at somebody on the phone. United Health Care is not being very nice to you right now. And you know we put this in I don’t know how long ago right since the last time I’d seen you. They have hemmed and hawed and hemmed and hawed and given all sorts of problems. Patient: What do I need to do? Doctor: I don’t know. Patient: Can I do anything. I mean…

Patient: Can I do anything. I mean… Doctor: Yeah I mean I think if we don’t get an answer today we’re gonna have to shoot somebody there. Doctor: That’s on video too. Yeah. Patient: We got this. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: Is there anything… Doctor: Well the good news is – no – I mean the good news is you know whether you get it today or next week, it doesn’t matter. You’ll still do well. Patient: But, okay, okay. Doctor: You’ll still do… Patient: That’s my only concern because because whoever called to schedule it said R__ you can do it before the holiday or do it afterward. Doctor: Yeah… Patient: We’ve got family coming and stuff like that too so… Doctor: So I think you should just do it after you know you finish radiation June eighth so that’s we’re covered and everything is great, your counts are fine. So you know you’re anemic is still at, your hemoglobin is still at eight point nine.

Family Member: Why are they not approving the chemo? Doctor: I have no clue. They don’t have to give a reason remember? They just say denied so then we’re like we don’t understand and then you play the round robin, you know talk to that person, talk to that person, at some point it’s gonna have to be talk to the Medical Director and I’m gonna be like this ain’t complicated. I would image it has probably a lot to do with you were on a trial and now you’re not and they’re behind right. So we’re moving at real time speed… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And stuff that they have is like always behind so you know there isn’t a – there isn’t a visit right now until right now for us to say well you’re done with that study, you’re now getting Taxotere just like a regular non-study patient and I’m sure they haven’t processes that in their head. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they go everything by notes. So everything for you has been on, on, on – oh we’re now going to get radiation, Patient: Okay. Doctor: so they don’t have a way to read and say that what I’m saying correct. Because if it’s not in a document then it isn’t so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And that’s a struggle for us, but I have a feeling that’s what it is. But hey this may be a blessing in disguise. You’ve got the fourth coming up, you might as well just enjoy it. We will reschedule next week. I’ll scream at a bunch of more people because what else do I have to do. Doctor: And then by then hopefully the shot will have worked out. Patient: Okay

Patient: Okay Doctor: If the shot doesn’t work out then we just have to stay very calm and either try a different shot which is a real pain in the neck shot because it’s an everyday shot for like three to four days that you would have to give yourself. Which if you can’t you would have to come here and we would give it to you, but that’s a cousin drug. Patient: Another chemo type. Doctor: No to get the white cells to remain up. Patient: Oh...Oh I see what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah remember this is a shot… Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know, I’m sorry. Patient: And you would recommend that at least at a minimum? Doctor: Well, you know there’s two ways to approach this. We could wait until you really are in trouble. And in trouble would mean you have a fever, you have no white cells, you better come in to the hospital, you need antibiotics. Patient: Yeah I don’t know (stammering) Doctor: But you’ve already demonstrated that your cells go down. You know you weren’t doing great. I just think we’re asking for trouble. So I’ve tried to explain that and they’re like is it a fever with no white cells. That’s all the understand. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know (sighs) Patient: Because I don’t mind making a phone call either but probably me stay out or what do you think? Doctor: Yeah it’s gonna be all how we code and get them… Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: So at this point anyway now that we’re in here now okay this is… Doctor: This is it.

Patient: In your, do you know what’s happening, I’m sure you do. Doctor: Yes. Patient: What’s happening now that I need more, sorry I don’t know why this happened but… Doctor: You got excited. Patient: Yeah (Laughing and all speaking at once.) Family Member: Take two. Patient: I’m just different, it happens here. Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill.

Patient: Why did you say it wouldn’t be – you just don’t think they work? Doctor: Well just in all the other patients that have sort of done that, they need to do it with something else. It’s just not strong enough. Patient: Okay, yeah, okay. I can’t say it goes away you know Doctor: Mm hmm. Patient: maybe it calms me down Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and something like that too, but nothing that I’ve had right now and I, I, I I’m not consistent with it. Doctor: Sure. Patient: It’s just something that we’ve tried – Doctor: Right. Patient: - been recommended that we try and I think we brought it up but… Doctor: Yeah. You know cancer is cancer, it’s got its own set of pain.

Patient: Well and… Doctor: Here’s the thing you got to take the medication. Patient: You want me to start to take a look at the Norco again or? Doctor: I think you should and just don’t let it get out of control you know, like I’d rather you take it occasionally or all the time if you need to. There’s no right or wrong on that. Family Member: It’s not that bad. Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure.

Patient: these three, four, five, six session of chemo – Doctor: Um, hmm. Patient: - what would be the best result in your opinion? Doctor: Well that you feel better, the PSA goes down to zero and the next imaging scans are rock stable. That’d be a homerun. It won’t ever really go away you know these things don’t change. Patient: The metastatic areas we see on the bones… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone?

Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And those are probably words that we opt to use. Um, If you have testicle cancer we could say remission Patient: Yeah. Doctor: because then you don’t see anything. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s nothing in the blood work all your scans are clean, then you can say wow I see nothing Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because you’re you’re just not going to be able to be strong enough. Other than that - Patient: Yeah. But strong enough now. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: But I mean from a fact that I guess I’m looking for the future Doctor: Of course, Patient: though too and this question that - Doctor: remember this is a marathon race. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: You know we can’t sprint from thing to thing you’ll be exhausted – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - and we won’t go anywhere. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we’re pacing you. Mm,hmm. Family Member: So, we’ve got four or five more chemos… Doctor: Yeah I think… Family Member: And then we’ll do a scan? Patient: Did you count this as one? Doctor: That was one. So I think we just need to sort of… Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either. Patient: In my world. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: In truly in my world. Doctor: Yes. Patient: I’m I’m, give me two seconds Doctor: Okay.

Patient: For a couple of days. Doctor: Yeah it’s that whole universal precaution. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Double flush your toilet. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It would be better if you had some sort of bleach product in your bathroom or your kitchen. Patient: Sure. Doctor: It’s probably better you don’t share your glasses. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So common sense stuff Patient: Okay. Doctor: would be important.
Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?

DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you.

Family Member: Prostate. Patient: For prostate. (Chuckles) Doctor: So in the end you’re taking the blood pressure medicine and the Vitamin D. Patient: Correct. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out.

Family Member: And tomorrow he’s, from the last night; tomorrow he’s scheduled to see a urologist uh uh they want to check him. Doctor: And would you get a flu shot? Family Member: Yes, he did while he was in the hospital. Doctor: So how are you feeling today? Patient: Fine. I feel pretty good the last seven days of the week or so. I moved around, worked on the computer. My wife won’t let me drive, so she drives me everywhere - Doctor: And do you have any pain? Patient: No. That is the question they keep asking me over and over; I really never have had pain. There was one time I had pain which is when I couldn’t urinate the second time when everything was blocked. That was and then that was pain was Patient: Right. Doctor: And you were in the hospital for seven days. Patient: Seven days. Yes and the numbers went from eight point six down to one point seven when it went out. Family Member: No, down to two point four. Patient: I’m sorry, yeah, to two point four, and then after that it was even more. So the last reading I had was Doctor: They didn’t put any tubes in your kidneys? They didn’t put inside your body?

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: Just the catheters. Family Member: Because he was improving; results were uh coming in. You know kidneys back into you know. Patient: They were getting better everyday, yeah. Doctor: They adjusted your blood pressure medicine. Patient: Correct. That is one thing that they did. They said the first time it was not good for the kidneys. Family Member: Actually when you came out it was two point two. And then a week later we went to see his uh - Patient: General practitioner and - Family Member: So what is the reading today? Doctor: One point zero. Family Member: Wow! Doctor: So that is what it’s supposed to be. A new one. (background noise persists in addition to keyboarding sounds)

Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. Looks like he can’t do anything for me except the nurse is taking catheter out and putting it in. So what other treatments he’s going to give me, I don’t know. Doctor: Dr. ____ or Patient: Dr. ____. Doctor: And the issue really is we’d like to get the catheter out and sort of when is your bladder strong enough to take it out, if we’ve shrunk the cancer with the hormone therapy – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - is there enough of a channel for you to pee on our own? Doctor: So all of that – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - is what urologists do. Patient: Right, I know. So anyway, I have it scheduled.

Family Member: Hormones - Uh is he getting more medicine today? Doctor: Well he got that shot; that shot lasts for three months Family Member: OHH! Patient: For three months? Oh, okay. I thought it was for three weeks. Doctor: Three months. Patient: Three months. Family Member: Three months. So at what point does the prostate shrink? Doctor: That’s our hope. Family Member: OHH! Patient: So should I be wearing this catheter for a while then? Doctor: Well because again it could be as early as this week that they feel like you can pee on your own. But if that’s what they’re going to be testing - Patient: And they cannot test it any other way except by pulling it out.

Patient: So those things I got – But I’m doing well. Doctor: Are you having hot flashes? Patient: How’s my what? Doctor: Are you having any hot flashes yet? Patient: No, no. They told me I may have hot flashes. Doctor: Any breast tenderness? Patient: No. Not anything. In fact everything is like it was before. Anything I’ve got besides this that I didn’t move the past week was Family Member: So would you suggest that he goes and see Dr. ____ uh when he’s scheduled or; now tomorrow he’s going to see - Patient: Another urologist. Family Member: A urologist that saw him up in the hospital, which is up in our area. Doctor: Yeah, I know that Dr. ____ reached out to you after you got to the hospital. So you know what he feels he can do versus there; most of what it sounds like is very just bread-and-butter urology. And you know um, we saw ya and we were worried that your kidney function had taken a bump. And it just got worse. And that’s why I want him to check it within a few days. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And within that few days it had already gotten worse and because your kidney function was bad, that makes you have nausea and then you sort of –

Patient: Right. Doctor: They come in, which, and you know when they looked at your picture um it really was where this was all started — that’s the problem because you can tell just by them just having to put a catheter in, that uh once your bladder gets empty and kidney functions get better. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh yeah so those are issues we have to talk about whether or not there is any role for radiation even though that’s not going to fix the big problem. It may help you pee better. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Um now since the cancer has spread, that the main problem Doctor: Uh huh. Family Member: - and the prostate is enlarged. Does it make any sense to remove it? Doctor: No, we wouldn’t operate on it. We would potentially radiate it. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yeah, I understood that it would not be removed. Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and…

Family Member: Okay, so you need to advise us and… Doctor: Well again I’m just getting more data as we’re talking here. Patient: I also sent saliva to do DNA test – Doctor: Uh huh. Patient: - and the thing has said it’s not hereditary. Family Member: That’s the copy. Doctor: Okay, I’ll take a look at it Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen.

Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do? Doctor: Yeah, so that; we have talked about that. You know your kidney function has gotten better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know so that is one of the key parts about you being eligible, that if your kidney function was too high, makes it difficult for us to use chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Chemotherapy with your numbers today, you could certainly go ahead and start moving forward with that and picking a date. You know for you to do the clinical trial then we do have to have you; D___ even kept an eye on you and let me know that you were in the hospital. You know we’ve got all kinds of I think Dr._____ one note said that Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in Doctor: And you definitely needed to be in the hospital then going closer to home is the right thing. And basically all they needed was to put a catheter in and then that was putting pressure off of your kidney. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: And you know we’ve got our fingers crossed that the hormones are going to be it and adding chemo to the clinical trial would be you know a step above that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The issue for the radiation you know is – one of the things is do we just watch. You know hormones to Dr. ____ that should be enough. Chemo is also going to try to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them? Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out.

Patient: Right, that’s what I was thinking originally, Family Member: And see what happens with medication. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Um, now about the uh hormone shots. So he’s covered for three months. After that expires he should get another shot and you start chemo? Doctor: He will have another shot, so it should be in here already. I will put it in. Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. Doctor: It is you know if you’re still interested in the clinical trial, have questions for me about the clinical trial, then I’m going to bring D___ in. So she’s the research nurse that I’ll sort of is it doable, can we get started, and what you have to do to go forward, okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once you guys sign the paperwork and we move forward, then you and I will pick a date to pick the day the chemo starts. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The computer makes the decision as to whether you get the extra drug or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And there always is the possibility that when you go through some of this checking, you’re not eligible. Patient: Um. Doctor: Okay, I think we have ninety days from when you got your first shot, which was November six or seven – Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: to get things going. And so that’s why I put this appointment on the books. So let’s get the hormones started. You know you will say, “I want it; I don’t want it; I do want it.” In other words I’m not trying to put, you know but we have to have and then your opinion back. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So we weren’t making any decisions. So I’m delighted today that you feel better, that you can’t complain of anything. Patient: Right. Doctor: Your creatinine is down at one. And then if you’re still interested, then we would go for it. If you say, “I’m not interested”, if you’re not interested then you have to think about when do we start you know the chemotherapy. And that’s what we would probably do anyway. If you go through the process about the trial and they say you’re not eligible, then we would give the chemo anyway. Patient: Yeah anyway. Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in.

Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: My sense is you guys are great communicators, that you know you have the catheters out, the catheter is not out. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And those are all sorts of things that again that again you’re going to probably need a face-to-face visit with D___ as you come back and so that will be also the time to update you as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, Dr. ___ was going to want to see you today because he enjoys working with you as well – Patient: Good.

Patient: Good. Doctor: - but because they’re filming – Patient: Now. Doctor: - uh they wanted to see me with you – Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Yeah (Chuckles) Doctor: So he’s still very much a part of the team. Patient: Good. Family Member: We like him very much. (Chuckles) Doctor: Okay, anything else? Patient: That’s it. Family Member: That’s it. Doctor: Let me see what we have in here in terms of just follow-up. So he’s already set up for his shot.

Patient: Right. Doctor: He’s just so you know because I guess your family and - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - his family are all sort of active, you know he’s very happy to you know be a part of that process, but also if you’re getting it locally and getting it done - Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so I’m not going to put any additional appointments in here. I’ll let D take it over from here. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me see if she’s out here to sort of get a sense that I can give you some feedback that it will be in the next day or the next week to sort of say to you - Patient: And then you will let us know about chemo Doctor: Yeah, we’ve got a little bit of a window, so we probably have until early February to get started. Patient: Oh so it won’t get started before that? Doctor: No, it could start as soon as you participate in the study, we can do that, but it’s not urgent that it has to be done before Christmas or before the new year’s or before Martin Luther King - Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Okay? Okay, let me see if she’s around so I can just give you a time frame um and uh thanks for bringing this in. This is very helpful. Patient: Good. Um hum. Family Member: We were happy when the results came in. Doctor: Yeah, no genes . Okay, great, good to see you. Family Member: Okay, thanks. Doctor: Happy holiday if I don’t see you before then. Patient: Happy holiday to you.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They put it in there. Patient: You can see the real thing if you’d like. It’s right there. (Laughs) Doctor: And, how are you doin’ with just the bowels, to start with? Still everything okay? Patient: Uh. With my bowels? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Actually, better. Doctor: Better? Okay. Patient: Since the radiation. Doctor: Okay. So, once a day, twice a day? How often do you --- Patient: Well, somedays a couple of times a day. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Maybe three times.

Patient: Yeah. Very. His name is D_, too. Doctor: Oh, okay. Well ---- Patient: He’s named for my son, I’m sure. She likes him a lot better than me. Family Member: That’s not clear. That’s – Doctor: Well, it looks like the PSA came down again. Patient: It came down a little bit. Doctor: Down to one point five. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think we’re probably hitting the bottom. Uh, which is okay. I, I think we have to sort of see how long we live there. Um. The, uh, the other thing that came back was your DNA test. Patient: The genetics. Doctor: Yeah, did you see that or not? Patient: No! I didn’t get a copy that I’m aware of. Uh, did you get it? Doctor: Yeah. So, it actually looks like, uh, (coughs)

Patient: Positive as in good news? Or – Doctor: No, that you’ve got a mutation. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, so, it’s kinda letting the genie out of the bottle a little bit once I tell you the results. Because, it has, you know, significance for your family. Family Member: And that’s what I was going to ask you. Patient: Hey! I want to know. Doctor: Okay. So, there’s a gene called BRCA2 which is – Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Associated with prostate and breast cancer. I’ll write it down for you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Um, that your – you have a mutation that you’ve inherited. What does that mean? Um. Well, we know that BRCA2 can be, um, a predisposition to getting prostate cancer. Patient: Well, I should tell you that -- I think it happened since I saw you – my brother was diagnosed.

Patient: No, she’s, she’s asking why wouldn’t people want to know. Doctor: Some people don’t want to know. Because now it’s an anxiety you gotta live with, and you know, it doesn’t necessarily mean one-hundred percent, but if you have it, it’s a very high chance that, particularly for breast cancer, you could get breast cancer. So. Patient: My, my children? Doctor: Your children. Patient: And my grandchildren? Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Everybody. Family Member: Not me, but yeah, them. Doctor: Right. Everybody that, so, you have one, it’s, it’s a mutation in the gene. You have two copies of the gene. It’s, you know, so there’s a one and four chance you could pass it on because two copies come from your, their mother, and so, the mother contributes one, you contribute one. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: There’s a fifty/fifty chance, you could contribute a good one or bad one, so they -- you know – does that make sense? Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that.

Doctor: But I’m going to ask you every time can you zip up your thing? Can you button your pants? Can you button your shirt? If you tell me I can’t, I’m going to stop. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now. Patient: This is experimental? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Patient: And uh so I would take the BET1 inhibitor and keep on the Xtandi? Doctor: That’s correct. Patient: And the Lupron? Doctor: So that’s an option. Okay? The other option is do we go now to the medications based on your BRCA mutation should we start you on Lynparza which is one of the medications that are basically given for BRCA mutation patients with prostate cancer. Okay.

Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is -- Patient: Would I continue on the Xtandi in that case or not? Family Member: Okay but she said there’s a third choice. Patient: Just a second, just a second, just a second I’m digesting this. Family Member: Sorry. Patient: Thank you. Ah… Doctor: I know it’s a lot of things to go through.

Patient: anyway so so, with that one I continue on the Xtandi with uh, um… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That’s not the PARP inhibitor? Doctor: Correct. And both medications would be provided by the study. Patient: And without the Xtandi? Doctor: Correct.

I mean the… Family Member: With the BET. Doctor: With the BET? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m thinking four to six weeks will give us at least an inkling if it’s doing something. Even if it’s stabilizes the PSA. We kind of have a clue that it’s doing what it’s supposed to. But to give it a fair trial, typically six to twelve weeks is required on any new medication I would say. Patient: Do you think that in the meantime the cancer will increase? Doctor: It seems very unlikely to me. Okay. Mainly because your scans haven’t changed. If they had… Patient: Except for the brightness. Doctor: Except for the brightness, yeah. If they had changed, you know if you had three new spots now, we would probably be having a different discussion. Family Member: So do you have any experience with the BET inhibitor? Have you seen it work or is it so new that you don’t really know? Doctor: I have experience with a different BET inhibitor. Doctor: There is some unknowns, quite a bit of unknowns, in terms of what side effects to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now the first few weeks of the study are gonna be fairly intense. There are two really long days where you have six-eight hour PKs with this study. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part.

Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. That’s what I read. Doctor: I know. Man. What happened here? Did you teach him stuff? Family Member: I didn’t, actually. Doctor: Wow. That’s great. Family Member: He’s a smart guy. Doctor: He is a smart guy. (Laughs) Patient: I used to do research for college professors sometimes in school. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: My sense is that this really was a new baseline just to make sure we're, you know, again, it's unusual for this to be real. Patient: Right. Doctor: But it's a possibility. I mean I just had a patient just before you his PSA was point three, something showed up, we put a biopsy and guess what it was prostate cancer- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -but that's not the norm. It doesn't make sense. And yet that's an example where it shows possibility. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know with you, you know what I worry about is sometimes you know, we write prostate cancer on the order form so the doctor over says, “Oh, yeah, there it is, there it is.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they may be right, or they may be calling what we normally if you had a scan and they’d say, “ that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis, that’s just arthritis”. Patient: Right. Doctor: Prostate Cancer likes to go to the lymph nodes, and so they're oft- they have to start small. And so we all have lymph nodes, but in this case, they say yeah, there’s lymph nodes-

Patient: Right. Doctor: -there's a lot of them, so that could be cancer. Patient: Right. DOC. They didn't say it was cancer. It could be cancer. Doctor: The stuff in your back Two different modes of how we look at your back are telling us different things about different places. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So the tiebreaker really would be to get another test. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we talked about an MRI which would tell us more about your back to see if there's something in the middle of the bone that would be cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could look at a PET scan, which you know, PSA is over point seven. These PET scans can be pretty good about picking up things. And basically they're just looking at how tumors are growing and if they’re growing, then they light up. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that we can do one of those scans and see how much lights up. Usually what…I don't like these tests because they tend to find what's under the radar. Because we know there's disease-

Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right.

Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay

Healthcare Professional: Just let me know when you’re done and I’ll come turn it off. Doctor: Okay, great. Thank you. Okay. Patient: Alrighty. Doctor: Okay. All right. So first we have to go over results. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So you have the CAT scan- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: -that showed probably no evidence of metastatic disease, okay, meaning no evidence of cancer that we can see. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The reason why I say probably- did you get these results on MyChart? Patient: Nuh-uh. Doctor: Okay, are you are you on MyChart? Family Member: We are, but we didn’t go on there.

Family Member: Okay Doctor: Okay, so that means that because your prostate is out, we know that the PSA is coming from the cancer, but there's not so much of it that we can see it, so it's there somewhere we just don't know exactly where it is. That, you got radiation for back in 2007 because usually, when prostate cancer recurs, it first recurs near the prostate. Am I making sense so far? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Then if it progresses, if you do nothing, you get metastatic disease. And that's when we can see the cancer somewhere in your body either on the CAT scan or the bone scan. So that's a CT or CAT scan or the bone scan because prostate cancer goes to the bone. So when you came to me you already had surgery for localized disease, you had already had radiation, which we sometimes use for our chemical occurrence- Patient: Mm. DOC- but you still had a rising PSA and we weren't sure if you were in this biochemical recurrence bucket or in this metastatic disease bucket. Okay. So, your imaging findings, so your CAT scan here shows…so here are the, this is the summary. I’ll just write summary. We can go through this. So, what this report shows- this is a CAT scan that shows coronary artery calcification, that means there's calcium build up in your around your heart. It's not uncommon for someone your age. Small atrial hernia not important. A thyroid nodule not that important. At some point, we can do a thyroid ultrasound, but we don't need to do anything about that right this moment. So this is what- is is maybe means that it's prostate cancer a small enhancing nodule in the left prostatectomy bed, which may reflect recurrence. So when you look in the full report, what they say is that there is a it's less than once every here is 0.7 by 0.9 centimeters, so then that's like less than one centimeter. So when it's that small, it's like, really difficult. It's actually like impossible to characterize it to say like, yes, this is definitively cancer or this is not cancer. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So that's why it says maybe, but they don't- notably, they don't see any anywhere else, okay. So then today you had your bone scan and the bone scans in shows no evidence of metastatic disease. Okay so these are your two summaries. Family Member: Mm. Doctor: So this is CT scan and this is bone scan. Okay. So those are you for your information. So with, with that you really fit into the bucket of what we consider biochemical recurrence. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Okay, which is good. Now the question becomes what do we do with you cuz you're in this bucket, biochemical recurrence. So you have a PSA that's rising the cancer somewhere, it seems to be growing, albeit maybe not that fast and before it gets to somewhere to metastatic what do we, what do we do? Okay, so the options for treatment at this point, are 1- observation- and observation what that entails is just monitoring your PSA and periodically doing CAT scans and bone scans and waiting to see if when you develop metastatic disease. Patient: Mm.

Patient: Mm. Doctor: Alright, and then starting treatment when you just when you develop metastatic disease. Option two is what we call intermittent hormone therapy. So, what this approach means is that you would get hormone therapy, which is the primary treatment for prostate cancer. If you were here in this metastatic bucket, you can get started with hormone therapy. But you would get started on hormone therapy for six months and then we stop and then and that'll bring down your PSA and then we wait until some threshold PSA, your PSA is about 31 now, so we could wait until it gets to 31 again. And sometimes we wait until it’s 10 sometimes 50, but you know, we would, we would only give you the hormone therapy intermittently, so not continuously so you get it for six months, two shots, shot us for three months, lasts for three months. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So you get it for two shots and then you stop. What this medicine does is it makes your testosterone levels go to zero. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they would ask about the dose as well. So at any rate, to answer your question that the advise on the Metformin is if you have another reason to be on it. Patient: Yes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay so the first thing would be to check and see uh if the cancer is still visible or invisible. In other words can we see the cancer on scan – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh. And the recommendation would be weaker; in other words, I would be open to delaying the hormone therapy a bit longer if the cancer cannot be seen. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In other words if it’s just the PSA rising and the absence of any visible cancer on the scan. Patient: At what point would you do the scan? Is it when it goes above one?

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: He was awarded a grant. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So because it was a transformative impact grant, we decided to call the trial the Transformer Trial. So this is a study where we’re testing this high-dose testosterone therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Now there are a few caveats about the trial that you need to be aware of. If your PSA goes above one after we do those scans (we can talk about that in more detail) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the purpose of this therapy, which we also call bipolar androgen therapy or BAT for short. We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. Patient: Excuse me; does it have to be Lupron or it could be another hormone? Doctor: It has to be an injectable testosterone-lowering medication. It doesn’t have to be specifically Lupron. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the reason I’m mentioning that is because a lot of patients do want to go on this therapy without being on the Lupron at the same time or a similar drug. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And the way that the trial is designed, if you give the testosterone without concurrently at the same time, suppressing the testosterone as well, then you don’t achieve these opposites between very high and very low levels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: What happens is over time is the testosterone just keeps increasing and increasing and increasing, and eventually it will begin to feed the cancer, at least in theory.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So that is why we give both drugs in combination. And what happens is on a monthly basis through about twenty-eight day treatment cycles the testosterone goes from being super-high, much higher than your body would be able to make on its own back down to super-low. PAT Uh huh. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So every twenty-eight days which is roughly every four weeks, your testosterone will spike for a few days and then within about a week it will drop down to the very low levels. Patient: When you say spike, what numbers have you seen? Doctor: Right, so I told you before that a real low testosterone level for someone your age might be let’s say a hundred fifty to two hundred milligrams per deciliter. Here, they’re talking about between one thousand and one thousand five hundred milligrams per deciliter. So it’s a five- to ten-fold increase above the physiological level. So we call this super-physiological. That means higher than physiological. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future –

Patient: Yeah, but if needs be, we can do it, we can do it. There’s another drug that we were on, too, besides Lupron. Doctor: It’s called Zytiga, also known as Abiraterone. Patient: It’s Zytiga. The testosterone has recovered. That would be ideal. Um. The next step is, you know, that we don’t get rid of your cancer with all of this and that your PSA goes up in the future. (pause) Doctor: Uh, because, we, we don’t normally cut out the ribs. I mean, that’s where we’re gonna offer radiation to that spot. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, that’s gonna treat that spot. Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then you and I just have to pick a day when you wanna start chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, some of it is, you can look at a calendar. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? You’re gonna come in two weeks which would be the twenty-first. You could theoretically get your first chemo then. Doctor: You could wait until the third of January, or you could -- Patient: Now, if you got - You, you – I grabbed that number out of the air. You can – Doctor: You could try to wait or things like that. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, he could wait. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Because, again, I like to wait a little bit. Patient: After the, uh, hormones?

Patient: After the, uh, hormones? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have some data that says says, um, people tolerate the chemo better once, uh, they have a little bit more space between getting the hormones and the chemo together. So Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let your body’s level of testosterone drop. Then, get the chemo, uh - that may be safer on your bone marrow than doing it all at once. Patient: That’s a done deal. Doctor: So, again, only that thing is, you know, if it, we don’t start ‘til early January. Then, you get six cycles. So, then we’re talking March. The surgery may not be ‘til April or early May. Patient: Any of those other things they oughta, where, like the, the hormones - let them ride for a little while before chemo. Any other - Family Member: Good to knows? Patient: Good to knows. (Laughs) Doctor: Yeah. Uh, some of it’s style. Okay? So, my sense is, you know, there’s a number of us doctors who are appointed patients under the study, and the study allows a lot of wiggle room, uh, for how we approach it. Uh. It’s a little concern of mine that all of us could do a little bit differently. But, you know, there’s general consistency about how to do it. So, for me, it’s a style that, uh, giving hormones and chemo together, uh, you can really drop your counts out if you haven’t given it a little bit of space. So, one of the other doctors just gives a lower dose of the chemo, and, uh, like, like, okay, but I would rather make sure you get a full dose of chemo, a full dose of hormones, and if I just space it out a little bit, then we can probably keep that safe. Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month?

Patient: Now, space it out a little bit, and I grabbed the number third of January, just outta the air. When you say “space it out a little bit,” from the beginning of the hormone treatment till, is it a week, ten days, a month? Doctor: Uh. Patient: Before you would start? Doctor: I mean, so we - in other studies, we’ve had up to about a four-month window that we could get the chemo started. In this study, it’s sorta that there is a definition, I think you said-- Healthcare Professional: It’s, umm. You’re talking about the protocols and parameters? Family Member: Yeah, the study itself. Doctor: Yeah. Thirty or sixty Healthcare Professional: Thirty days, I do believe. From the, um, the, the Doctor: From the hormone first Healthcare Professional: hormone first. Doctor: Right, so if he gets this hormone therapy on the twenty-first, then Healthcare Professional: On the twenty-first, then he could. December. Probably, uh, we could stretch it out to the end of December. Doctor: Okay.

Healthcare Professional: Yeah. We can get you started. Family Member: What are the pills? Doctor: Uh, the pills are bicalutamide. So, basically, they, uh, block, uh, your cancer cell from using testosterone that’s in your body. So, right away, they start treating your cancer. Uh. But, when I give you your shot, uh, the testosterone shoots up. It could make your cancer worse in that few days. And, so, I wanna protect that surge of testosterone that occurs when we give you the first shot. Patient: Hmmm. Family Member: The first shot of the hormone? Doctor: The first shot of the hormones. Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh.

Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. Hhh (chuckles) Family Member: So, until Doctor: So, I’ll, I’ll start that. You’re gonna need to sign a permission and all that with T_. Healthcare Professional: Yep. Doctor: And, she’ll go over all the, the, the other detail, which you’ve already read. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. That has to start with - I just, again, if we, if the advice was to start same day, I would. If you wait four weeks, we will pick a date four weeks out and start then. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um -

Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if

So what it is, is it’s a radiation, a type of radiation that you would get, but it’s tagged to something called PSMA. Family Member: Okay. With what? Doctor: P-S-M-A. Family Member: Oh. P-S-M-A. Doctor: Which is, uh, antigen that a lot of the prostate cancers produce. So what it- what that treatment does, is it attaches to that antigen on the cancer cells and releases the radiation right where the cancer is at. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That is the idea behind it. I mean, he would definitely need a blood draw and all that. Family Member: Right. Doctor: All that screening would happen here. Family Member: Right.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Then, we schedule that trip. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? And on that scan, if it looks like your cancer is expressing the PSMA, then we would start looking into whether we, uh, you know, then we can put you on the study. Doctor: Now, even after you get enrolled on it, though, there is a one in three chance that you may not get the actual treatment. Family Member: You’re talking about placebo? Doctor: Yeah. So there is a two out of three chance that you will have a chance to get that medication. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: If, if I need that medication, I could though? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Can I go to England and get it?

Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh-

Patient: Yeah. That’s a good point. Right. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, I think if you want to explore that, my feeling would be if you can get it on the study, well and good. Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles)

Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s - Doctor: Yeah, and the cold right now - Patient: And the cold and sitting - Doctor: And the other thing is as you lose your hair, since we’re doing this right in the middle of winter, you have to protect your head. Family Member: Yeah. Yes. Doctor: Because that’s a sudden change that your body in this cold will really have a tough time getting used to. Yes. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. Once in a while I guess if you have a major reaction, it’s okay to have it - Family Member: And so - Doctor: My hope is if this is a lot of this flare-up from the pain from the cancer, then actually we should start seeing an improvement ah without having to do - Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see.

Patient: But where do you draw the line as to how much you can take, you know? Well - Doctor: I don’t know. Well, that’s the problem. Doctor: on top of the Zytiga. Now two/three years later, the study that they did of the combination is reporting way more factures and issues. Family Member: OOH! Doctor: So those were surprising Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: effects that nobody expected. Patient: Am I going to be sterile now? Family Member: Oh Jesus! (chuckle) Doctor: No, there’s no reason for you to. Not from the chemo.

Doctor: So, yeah, when we saw you, you already had Abiraterone, enzaluta – Radium, docetaxel. And, so what we do next, uh, you know, the only thing you haven’t had is, uh, chemotherapy. Doctor: Um. So, uh. Patient: The enzalutamide. I, I don’t remember being on that.

Something that’s not hormone therapy. Patient: Okay. Is that the – Doctor: Xtandi. Patient: Xtandi. Okay. That was a shot once a month or? Doctor: That was the pills you were taking. Patient: Oh, I did take them. Yeah. Okay. Doctor: So that would say if we did that just as a course of action and the likelihood it’s gonna help you is pretty low. Patient: Oh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, it has less side effects than chemotherapy but has more risks than chemotherapy because if we do turn on your immune system really good, attack you, you could be bad. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: That’s if it ends up going bad versus -- uh, activated immune system. Doctor: We often use steroids, and we try to sort of dampen it – Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And some folks – most people recover. Uh, but we have to hold the drugs, not hold the drugs, and then, -- yeah, so it’s a catch twenty-two, uh, that, you know, it also is for individuals like you who again have some factor that tells us that your cancer is not gonna bode well with, you know, your survival from this cancer is not, you know, tremendously long. Patient: I, I was told I’ll see another Christmas. Doctor: Yeah. That could be true, or it could be a little bit longer. But, again, most of the time when we’ve used the docetaxel – the Taxotere that you got that you started in the fall? Uh. We tell folks that from that setting, we sort of says that people live fifteen to twenty months. Eh, so that’s when we may get to the end of this year. Uh. And so that’s where you also may step back and say, “Whoa. If time is short, I don’t want to be sick. I don’t want to have to go to the doctor. I don’t wanna be all of this other stuff. Uh. Let me focus on me.” Okay? And work on just keeping you comfortable. ‘Cuz right now, you’re comin’ and goin’, gettin’ exhausted at five o’clock. You’re takin’ your nap and – you know, getting your cleaning done the next day. Patient: Five. Yeah. So. Doctor: So, that is – some people do just sort of say, “Look. You know, I’ve been through everything, and I don’t know if I can do much more. And I wanna just sort of be comfortable.” Other folks say, “Okay. There’s more drugs? Give ‘em to me.” Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Chemo is the only thing that we know right now – the one that your doctor said may not do a whole lot – he doesn’t have much faith in it is what I think what you told me. Is again, we do know that if you get the drug, tolerate the drug, respond to the drug, people live longer, but again, that’s got an if, if, if. Um. So, that would be what usual is, and then this is research, experimental. Would require you coming down here every other week for a couple of weeks. Patient: Ah huh. Doctor: Uh, and then, uh, every two weeks, three weeks, once you get past the first part, you’re here a lot – so that’s for us to watch you, keep close eye on you as well as to see what the side effects are. Uh. But for you, it’s a downside of coming a distance, coming here a lot, feeling tired, feeling fatigued, and with the uncertainty is this going to do anything? Patient: Right. (Pause) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But again, if you’re driving, folks driving, getting you here, and again you can go out of this world sayin’, “I’ve tried everything ‘till the end.” Okay? But I still think you need to be careful and pay attention to this. Okay? Because if something goes really bad with this – let’s say you get a bad pneumonia, and we want to put you on a breathing machine even though the steroids may be able to bring you back, we don’t know that. But if it gets to a point, you know, I’m not sure you really should be on a breathing machine. Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found)

I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost? Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner. Patient: I have a panty liner. Just like in case I sneeze, cough. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That’s I mean I’m full exercising. Doctor: Uh hum. That’s okay, good. So you’re not leaking when you exercise? Patient: No, no. no. Doctor: Oh good. Okay, so really going forward, there are sort of two approaches that folks take. The standard of care is that you um would get uh radiation to your pelvis, uh and most people, given the amount of disease you have down there, we also recommend that you get hormone therapy with the radiation.
