Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive.

Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So that’s quite frankly that’s a, it’s a clinical trial we offer, but because of a stupid loophole which I didn’t realize I can’t put you on the clinical trial because you were on the other one. (Laughs) Patient: Right. Doctor: And uhm it’s a loophole I’m going to fix. Patient: Uh hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: Can I tell you how much that’s gonna increase the fifty/fifty odds? No. Can I tell you that that’s the most aggressive thing we can do for this cancer right now anywhere in the world? Yes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s what you know basically how I take care, how I try to take care of guys like you who are young and I want to hit the cancer really hard. Patient: Right. Doctor: So your choice basically is radiation with hormones or if you want to try a super sort of therapy, with chemo, super hormones, we can do that. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: The super hormones for the three months also make you more tired, but not really that much more because once we lower your testosterone down to what we call castrate levels, to go from castrate to super castrate, people don’t complain about more tiredness. Patient: Right. Doctor: So um there are some things we watch and your blood tests to make sure you’re tolerating the drugs all right, but that’s not the big issue. Tiredness is the issue. So then we add chemo in and really we give the chemo to you four times on a Monday – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - three weeks apart. Um, the the actual um chemo itself, you don’t get sick, you don’t throw up. We have all the medicines that stop that from happening. Anything that throw up We’re just really good at it. Uhm, Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Uhm and you’re in remission unless it recurs, comes back. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Last question, or uh maybe not. Mistletoe. I don’t have to be a rabbit anymore? We might have to change this little tail that I’m growing.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Be to go to a intravenous chemotherapy. Okay. I don’t think I’m going to recommend that for you right now because your symptoms seem to be relatively mild. I’m not fully convinced to whether the pain that you had yesterday was attracted to cancer or could’ve been through something . I’ll try this route Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The chemotherapy has a name. It’s called Docetaxel and it has a second name and that is Taxotere. And this is given through the vein, intravenous, also called I.V. Intravenous I.V. It’s given once every few weeks. And I’m writing this down as an option just so you know what we talked about. But at this point in time, um I think that your cancer is progressing relatively slowly, if at all. Probably at slowly. And I don’t see any immediate need right now to recommend the chemotherapy. But it is an option, we’ll save that for later. I wanna focus our conversation now on the fresh option, which is the Xtandi. So in general in patients who have previously received Abiraterone, that could’ve been you, you would’ve been taking it but you were unable to get access to it for the last two months. Patient: Right. Doctor: If if that is no longer affected then the second drug, Xtandi, uh typically works for about six, sometimes nine months. So it, it doesn’t work for years and years but it does give us a little bit more time before we have to recommend the chemotherapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: One of the things we have been interested in is how do we make this drug work better and longer. Okay. And one way to make this drug better, work better and longer is to try to combine it with a second drug that’s experimental. Okay. So the Xtandi itself is not experimental, this has been approved by the FDA more than five years ago. It’s standard, does not require you to participate in a clinical trial and I could just write you a prescription for this medication. The experimental clinical trial that we’re doing which is research, so you would have to sign a permission slip which we call a consent form. Not today but after we’ve had time to look at it. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Um and I’ll just flip the page to the back. Okay. It’s a randomized trial. What does randomized mean? Randomized means that at the beginning of the study we flip a coin. Might sound crazy. Doctor: So, I’m going to write randomized. And that coin flip is random. In other words, neither the doctor nor the patient can influence it. We can’t rig the system. Once the coin has been flipped, we can’t flip it again. We can’t keep flipping it until we get the one that we want. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So in this study there are two options. One option is patients get the Xtandi. That’s the same thing that I’ve written on the the top of this page. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Okay. So option number one is to get the same drug that I would have recommended anyway as part of your standard care. Option number two is the combination of Xtandi plus the new experimental drug, which has a long name. It’s called G__?___. And this second drug has been shown in the laboratory, not yet in patients but in the laboratory, that makes the Xtandi work better and longer. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And one of the things that this drug does, although it does many other things as well, is that it can boost the immune system. So one of the reasons why cancer can grow and progress in a person’s body, is because the immune system isn’t able to attack and kill the cancer cells fast enough. And the cancer cells can make some chemicals that can switch off those immune cells. recognizing and killing the cancer. What this drug is it tries to stimulate that immune system again so it can recognize the cancer. But it does that in conjunction with the Xtandi. Now, I didn’t mention this before but this medication is also a pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s a question of taking two pills versus one pill. Okay. There’s a forty percent chance that the coin will flip coin will flip in that direction and you will be selected to take only the Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: And there’s a sixty percent chance that the coin will flip and you will get selected to receive the combination, the FDA approved drug plus the experimental drug. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: This is not a drug that even if I really wanted you to get on this group, I could just prescribe. Because not been FDA approved for any cancer type, um certainly not for prostate cancer. Um, but the thing that I always want people to understand, when it comes to this clinical trial is, that if you decide you you want to participate in it, you need to conscious of both scenarios. In other words, if you know in your heart of heart-heart’s that you’re going to drop out if you don’t need the new drug (beeper sounds) Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication.

Doctor: Um some people can have a uh decreased energy or they might feel more tired. Um but I, I would have to say in general these side effects are all better than what we see in chemotherapy. And then addition to that, possibly to consider the clinical trial. But at the very least, I do think Xtandi is going to be a part of your treatment. Patient: Oh, okay. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh- Patient: About this? Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? She wanted to end all this crazy stuff. Family Member: I don’t think it’s crazy stuff. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Doctor: Now, the survival part’s tricky because that’s the whole group, and some of the men, so, you look at the number total, it’s only, you know, a couple of months’ difference between the guys that get the drug and the guys that don’t. But within that group, there are some people that respond really well and really long who probably are getting much more than a couple of months, and there’s some people where it doesn’t do anything, and they’re probably getting nothing out of it. So, uh, the other thing they look at in the trials is something called a, sort of a risk reduction. So there’s pretty significant reduction in dying from prostate cancer if you’re on, if you take the drug. So in my experience, what I’ve seen is about a third of the men I give the drug to, their PSA drops, and they have a really long response that usually long means somewhere between, well, I’ve only been using it, you know, a couple of years now, but two to three years sometimes. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: One, one to three years, maybe, let’s say. It just marches along. In your case, that’s going to be the primary thing for us because the bone, like I said, it’s hard to measure changes. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, and the, the biggest fact from the drug was in men before chemotherapy, it’s probably just because they were earlier in their disease-

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? Uh, the other thing to say about Zytiga, is it’s going to be generic soon, but I’m not sure it, if we’re quite there yet. I’m not sure. I can find that out. But, uh, so if you tell me, geez, I really don’t want to take prednisone, then I would do the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Otherwise, I would do the Zytiga. Patient: Yeah. I don’t really want to take prednisone. I saw how it affected her. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Then I would just proceed with the Xtandi and start it. Okay? (Sound Door closes) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The other piece of this that’s an unknown piece is, we have some sets that the people who got testosterone, even the ones that didn’t respond to it, seemed to have a better response to drugs like Xtandi or Zytiga afterwards. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And our, our idea is maybe that the cells have gotten used to being low testosterone and they’ve kind of adjusted. Then we put them in high testosterone, they adjust to that- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the idea is if we combine them together, would they work together? And there’s some evidence that radiation makes the immune system work better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So the complicating part about that study is that the vaccine, you know, is a little involved. You have to go to the Red Cross. They’ve got to call some, they have to kind of hook you up to a machine that kind of pass your blood through and pull out the, the cells that they’re going to make the vaccine out of. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And so it’s, it’s, you know, you’ve got to do a little bit of work to get the vaccine. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right.

Doctor: So, they’ve, they’ve tested it in Europe in a, in a weird way. So in Europe, the doctors there are allowed to, if they think something could work, they’re allowed to just give it to people. They don’t need FDA kind of approval. Doctor: They don’t need, uh, even data showing that it proves survival. It’s sort of, if, if the doctor feels it could be beneficial, they’re allowed to use it. So they’re not allowed to sell it. They not allowed to make money. So what they’ve been doing is based on using the same material to image prostate cancer. So we give this material with a little bit of radiation on it and it looks really good. We could see spots that we maybe didn’t see before. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: The idea was, well, if we can swap out the little bit of radiation and put a lot of radiation, maybe we could treat cancer. So they’ve been treating people kind of on an individual basis. Somebody calls up, shows up, you give it to them. They haven’t said, let’s take a hundred guys with this, you know, kind of like a trial. So they’ve been reporting look how good Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So in the U.S., we kind of have to go down more organized, you know, step-wise fashion. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And for reasons that are complicated related to business and how, you know, how these things happen. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So far, until recently, this hasn’t been in the right hands, I think, to make a drug out of it. Recently, there’s been a lot of interest and a very large company bought the rights to it, and I think they’re going to do it correctly. But it’s been a slow moving thing to get started. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And, and some of the complexity relates to, to, uh, how the drug’s supplied. Anyway, so that, that is a radioactive thing that’s coming. The radium, we could do that as just a standard treatment, not even part of a trial. Patient: Um hum.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: The trial, yeah. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. I’ll, I’ll clarify that today. Okay? As soon as we’re done. Uh, there’s two different groups I’ve got to talk to, uh, about that. Uh, then I will, uh, I’ll get that information to you as soon as I have it. And if I don’t- Family Member: But one, one of them you said that he’d get both drugs. So he’d probably want to do that one, I guess. Because one you get one and the other one you’re going to get both. You just get the- Patient: You talking about the one with the prednisone? Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec)

Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: So I will call you probably Friday- Patient: Okay. Doctor: With some information. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows.

Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico- Patient: Right. I know. Yeah. That is. That is. Doctor: Unless it’s for a healer. You know? Patient: Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: That is no good. Patient: Yeah. Remember when I was telling you about that, uh, um, HIV drug that they were doing some sort of testing on that was very good for, what was that, brain tumors? (Sound Door closes) Doctor: Yeah. So, I think they’re calling this the same thing. Vitamin B-seventeen is the laetrile?

Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they- Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday.

Patient: Yeah. The elephant, giraffe, lions. Doctor: And where did you go? What like park or what was? Family Member: Kruger National Park. Patient: Kruger. Doctor: Kruger. Yeah. I’ve heard about that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: They say it’s the large- it’s about the size of Connecticut. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So, actually, we was there most of the day. We was like falling asleep on the safari because you’ve got a, they gotta run and catch the animals. Patient: Oh. No. We went to lunch. We went to lunch. (& FAM talking the same time) Doctor: So you’re just kind of driving around, and they’re like, hey, there’s a, there’s a giraffe or something? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (Laughter)

Family Member: Open trucks. Doctor: I have a patient, one of my patients is a guy with a lot of money, and he and his wife do this. But, you know, they do it like only people with a lot of money can do it. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: And he’s like, oh, yeah, we’re going and we stay in these tents. Patient: Oh, you can. Doctor: And his wife’s like, yeah, they’re not really tents, though. They like have king-size bed. You know? They’re like- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So they’re like, not like the tent I’ve got. Pop-up and sleep on an air mattress. Patient: They have stuff- Family Member: Right. Patient: They have stuff out there where people can stay out there. I wouldn’t stay out there, man. Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Couldn’t handle that flight. Oh, gosh. Family Member: The flight is so long. Doctor: Did you fly like connect somewhere? Patient: Yeah. We had to go to Dubai. And then from Dubai, was nine hours to Dubai. Doctor: Nine hours to Dubai? Then how long? Patient: From Dubai to South Africa was nine hours. Doctor: How far to Dubai? It’s like twelve hours? Patient: Oh, man, it was about fourteen, sixteen hours. Doctor: Man, you guys are- Doctor: You had to travel. Doctor: Yeah. They do like the circle route, I guess. Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it.

Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think like taking a globe and a string or something and see. Patient: Yeah. I didn’t understand why- Doctor: I don’t quite understand how it’s shorter, but it’s shorter. Family Member: But we could see on the plane, you know, on the screen the pattern he’s flying in- Doctor: Yeah. You go up. Right. You go up along Canada. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: There’s a part over Canada where you cross, there’s like a big bay, I think the jet stream. It gets real choppy there. You get a lot of turbulence. I always know- Family Member: Yeah. We did. Doctor: And one time, I don’t know where I was, but I remember looking out the window. I could see Greenland. Doctor: I could see actually. Because usually when the times I’ve flown, it’s either dark or cloudy, but this is one like, holy crap, and my phone even said, welcome. Doctor: You know when you fly sometimes, your cell phone will pick up. I must not have had it turned off. It said, like welcome to Greenland. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God.

Patient: Oh, shoot. Oh, God. Doctor: But that’s a lot of travelling, man. Family Member: It’s very interesting. Patient: Oh, my goodness. Whew. That plane ride was a trip. Family Member: We was, uh, kind of like laughing come down here to Baltimore. We were like, Baltimore’s not too far from South Africa with the living conditions. You know? Patient: With how some of these people live. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages-

Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-? Patient: No. Family Member: Yeah. We did go to the beach one day. Patient: We went to the beach but we didn’t get in it. Family Member: It was the Indian Beach. Patient: Yeah. We didn’t get in. Doctor: What’s the Indian Beach?
